isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 2000, 4000, 8000 - BATTERY, CHARGING AND CRANKING SYSTEMS - TROUBLESHOOTING - Starting Motor System Circuits And Components

svcproc.title: Starting Motor System Circuits And Components

title.hotlnk: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 (With International Engine)

svcsubproc.para: Starter shifting in and out, or not pulling in, is often caused by high resistance in the starter solenoid circuit. When the solenoid circuit has excessive voltage loss, the starter pinion sometimes may not engage the flywheel. If it does engage, it may drop out too soon when battery voltage drops. The solenoid circuit includes the starter relay (located center of bulkhead) and leads connected to the starter solenoid.
On vehicles with overcrank protection, refer to Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection System before performing this test.

step1.para: Disconnect starter relay circuit 17C from the starter solenoid "S" terminal.

Connect the carbon pile positive lead to circuit 17C and the negative lead to the starter ground. Connect the positive lead of a DMM voltmeter to the solenoid "B" terminal. Connect negative lead of voltmeter to switch wire lead 17C (not to carbon pile clamp). Meter will show battery voltage.

Have an assistant turn the key switch to the start position or push start button. Voltmeter reading should be zero. You should hear the starter relay switch energize with a clicking sound. If the switch doesn't "click," either the starter relay switch is defective or there is no voltage from the key switch circuit (refer to Engine Crank Inhibit System Circuit Test (With International Engine).

Turn on and adjust the carbon pile to 50 amp load (for no more than 10 seconds). Read and record __________voltage on voltmeter. Release start switch. Turn off and disconnect carbon pile and voltmeter.

svcsubproc.para: If circuit loss is 0.5 volt or less, solenoid circuitry is OK. Go to Engine Crank Inhibit System Circuit Test.
If circuit loss is more than 0.5 volt, go to Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2 below.

figure.caption: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 (With International Engine)

title.hotlnk: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2 (Wire Voltage Loss) (With International Engine)

svcsubproc.para: If the voltage loss in the previous Test was more than 0.5 volt, the loss is excessive. The loss may be from loose terminals, corrosion, or a worn out starter relay switch. To locate the problem:

step1.para: Disconnect circuit 17C from "S" terminal at starter solenoid. Connect carbon pile to circuit 17C and to starter ground terminal. Turn the carbon pile on (will show 0 amps).
Disconnect starter relay and install a jumper lead to cavity E, circuit 17B.

note.para: Test lead will be at battery voltage.

step1.para: Connect DMM from solenoid BAT terminal to start relay connector cavity E, circuit 17B (will show zero volts).

At relay connector, install other end of jumper lead to cavity A circuit 17C. Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 50 amp load (no more than 10 seconds). Read and record first wire voltage loss. Disconnect DMM.
At relay connector, connect DMM from cavity A, 17C to circuit 17C at carbon pile. Connect to terminal and not to carbon pile clamp.
Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 50 amp load (no more than 10 seconds). Read and record second wire voltage loss. Disconnect and remove jumper lead and DMM.

svcsubproc.para: First Wire Loss (step 3) ________
plus Second Wire Loss (step 5) ________
equals Total Wiring Loss = _________(0.4V maximum loss)
If wiring loss is 0.4 volt or less, repair or replace wire(s), and retest per Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1, above.
If wiring loss is more than 0.4 volt, repair or replace wire(s), and retest per Part 1.
If retest results are still above 0.5 volt loss, replace starter relay and retest per Part 1.

figure.caption: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2 (Wire Voltage Loss) (With International Engine)

title.hotlnk: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 (Without International Engine)

svcsubproc.para: Starter shifting in and out, or not pulling in, is often caused by high resistance in the starter solenoid circuit. When the solenoid circuit has excessive voltage loss, the starter pinion sometimes may not engage the flywheel. If it does engage, it may drop out too soon when battery voltage drops. The solenoid circuit includes the starter magnetic switch and leads connected to the starter solenoid.
On vehicles with overcrank protection, refer to Testing Thermal Overcrank Protective System before performing this test.

step1.para: Disconnect circuit 17B from the starter solenoid "S" terminal. Connect the carbon pile positive lead to circuit 17B and negative lead to the starter ground. Connect the voltmeter positive lead to the solenoid battery stud and the negative lead to the starter motor ground stud (not to carbon pile clamp).

Have an assistant push the start button or turn key switch. The magnetic switch should energize with a clicking sound. If the switch doesn't "click," either the switch is defective (refer to Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test) or there is no voltage from the key switch circuit.

Adjust the carbon pile to 100 amp load. Read and record cable voltage. Release start button or key switch. If the reading is more than 0.5 volt lower than the value shown in the table in Battery Test, perform that test and Battery Cable Voltage Loss Test.
Move the voltmeter negative lead from the starter motor ground stud to the end of circuit 17B that is connected to the carbon pile. Do not connect to carbon pile clamp.
Push and hold the start button again and re-adjust the carbon pile load to 100 amps. Read and record solenoid voltage. Release the start button or key switch.
Cable Voltage (step 3) ___________
minus Solenoid Voltage (step 5) __________
equalsCircuit Loss = __________
If circuit loss is 1.0 volt or less, go to Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 1.
If circuit loss is more than 1.0 volt, go to Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2, below.

figure.caption: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 (Without International Engine)

title.hotlnk: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2 (Wire Voltage Loss) (Without International Engine)

svcsubproc.para: If voltage loss in Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 was more than 1 volt, the loss is excessive. The loss may be from loose terminals, corrosion, or a worn out start magnetic switch. To locate the problem:

step1.para: Leave carbon pile connected as in Part 1.
Connect DMM positive lead to solenoid "BAT" stud and negative lead to large terminal of magnetic switch. If voltage shows on meter, move meter lead to the other large magnetic switch terminal.
Push start button with key on or turn key switch to start position. Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 100 amp load. Read and record first wire voltage loss. Release start switch.
Connect DMM positive lead to other (opposite) large terminal on magnetic switch and negative lead to circuit 17B (not to carbon pile clamp).
Push start button or turn key switch to start position. Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 100 amp load. Read and record second wire voltage loss. Release start switch.
First Wire Loss (step 3) __________
plus Second Wire Loss (step 5) __________
equals Total Wiring Loss = __________(0.8 volt maximum loss)
If circuit loss is 0.8 volt or less, go to step 6.
If circuit loss is more than 0.8 volt, repair or replace wire, then go to step 6.
Connect DMM across the two large magnetic switch terminals (battery voltage will show immediately).
Push start button or turn key switch to start position. Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 100 amp load. Read and record _____ voltage loss across the magnetic switch. Release start switch.
If the voltage drop is greater than 0.2 volt, replace the magnetic switch.
Remove carbon pile. Leave circuit 17B disconnected (use tape to insulate) to perform Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 1 (Without International Engine), following..

figure.caption: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2 (Wire Voltage Loss) (Without International Engine)

title.hotlnk: Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 1 (Without International Engine)

svcsubproc.para: A magnetic switch that does not close or drops out too soon can be caused by high resistance or an open in the control circuit.

step1.para: Disconnect circuit 17B from start solenoid "S" terminal and insulate with tape. Connect voltmeter positive lead to the starter solenoid "BAT" stud and negative lead to the starter motor ground stud.

Have an assistant push the start button (with key on) or turn key to start position. You should hear the magnetic switch relay "click." If not, proceed anyway. Read and record battery cable voltage. Release start switch.
Connect the voltmeter positive lead to the small magnetic switch terminal and the negative lead to the switch ground screw. (Magnetic switch is internally grounded through the mounting.)
Have an assistant push the start button (with key on) or turn key to start position. Read and record magnetic switch voltage. Release the start switch.

svcsubproc.para: Battery Cable Voltage (step 2) ________
minus Magnetic Switch Voltage (step 4) ________
equals Control Circuit Wiring Loss = ________
If circuit loss is 1.0 volt or less and the magnetic switch closes, circuit is OK.
If circuit loss is 1.0 volt or less and the magnetic switch doesn't close, replace the switch and repeat the test.
If circuit loss is more than 1.0 volt, go to Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 2, below.

figure.caption: Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 1 (Without International Engine)

title.hotlnk: Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 2 (Without International Engine)

svcsubproc.para: If Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 1, above, has shown a voltage loss greater than 1.0V, perform this test using a digital multimeter (DMM). Leave circuit 17B disconnected from the starter solenoid.

step1.para: With the key on and start button depressed or key switch in start position, and the voltmeter leads in the positions shown for each step:

step2.para: Measure magnetic switch to starter motor ground. If reading is within 1.0 volt of battery voltage, repair magnetic switch ground. If reading is not within 1.0 volt of battery voltage, go to Step B.
Measure and record ______ solenoid to key voltage.
Measure and record ______ key switch voltage.
Measure and record ______ key to start button voltage.
Measure and record ______ start button voltage.
Measure and record ______ start button to magnetic switch voltage.

svcsubproc.para: TOTAL ______ (1.0V MAX. ALLOWED)
If greater than 1.0 volt, repair or replace any circuit or component with excess voltage loss.

If any of the circuits or component checks (B through F) show full battery voltage with the start button depressed or key switch in start position, then an open circuit exists in the portion of the circuit between the DMM leads. Repair that portion and connect circuit 17B to the starter solenoid.

figure.caption: Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 2 (Without International Engine)

item.para: Cold Weather Start Magnetic Switch Problems

The starter magnetic switch, or start relay (with International engine), can fail to "hold in" during cold weather cranking due to low voltage, even though the switches and circuits check OK. This failure sounds as though the starter is failing to stay engaged to the flywheel. It is caused by low system voltage releasing the magnetic switch or relay.

If this condition exists, have an assistant clamp a heavy battery jumper cable between the two big (5/16 inch) studs on the magnetic switch or with International engine, install jumper wire from circuit 17B to 17C at starter relay connector. Caution - The studs are at battery voltage and the engine should crank when the jumper is connected. Remove jumper to stop cranking.If the engine cranks properly with jumper in place, replace the magnetic switch or relay and make sure starter mounting bolts are tight.
If all previous tests have been performed, the vehicle batteries and starter wiring have been checked. If the engine still cranks slowly, check available voltage at the starter.

step1.para: While cranking engine, measure voltage between the starter solenoid "BAT" stud and starter motor ground.

step2.para: If voltage is 9.0 volts or more, the problem must be in the starter (or engine). Replace the starter.
If the voltage is less than 9.0 volts, go to step 2.

step1.para: Check the interconnecting cable between the batteries. While cranking, measure the terminal voltage of each battery by touching voltmeter leads to the post of each battery.

step2.para: If the difference between any two battery readings in the same battery box is more than 0.5 volt or any cable is warm to the touch, replace the interconnecting cables.
If cables check OK, the problem must be in the starter (or engine). Replace the starter.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Crank Inhibit System Circuit Test (With International Engine)

note.para:
Perform test Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 (With International Engine)
before conducting the following test.

table.title: Engine Crank Inhibit System Circuit Test (With International Engine)

entry.para: Using suitable jumper, jump crank motor solenoid "B" terminal to "S" terminal. Does crank motor operate?
Go to Starter Motor Replace- ment Test above.
Remove start relay (387). At conn. cavity 2, measure voltage from circuit 17F to ground.
At (387) cavity 1, measure voltage from circuit 17B to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17-FL/17B, then repair.
At conn. (387), measure voltage across cavity 1 circuit 17B to cavity 4 circuit 17C.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17C, then repair.
At connector (387), measure voltage across cavity 1 circuit 17B, to cavity 5 circuit 17D.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuits 17D or 17-G/11-GJ, then repair. Install relay. If equipped with thermal overcrank protection, refer to Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection Systembelow.
Remove crank inhibit relay (661). With auto. trans. in neutral or clutch pedal depressed, turn key on and at cav. 1, measure voltage from circuit 97L to ground.
At (661) cavity 2, measure voltage from circuit 17 to ground.
At (661) cavity 4, measure resistance of circuit 17F to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 17F, then repair.
Bench test relay (661) by measuring resistance from terminal 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (661) by applying +12V to pin 85 and ground to pin 86. Measure resistance across terminal 30 to 87.
Disconnect ECM conn. (379). Turn key on. With automatic transmission in neutral or with clutch pedal released, measure voltage at cavity 26, circuit 97A to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 97A, or dash connector (3), then repair.
With manual trans. and clutch pedal depressed, at (379) cavity 26, measure voltage from circuit 97A to ground.
At crank inhibit relay conn. (661) cavity 5, install jumper from circuit 97H to ground. At (379) cavity 46, measure resistance of circuit 97H to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 97H or dash conn. (3), then repair. If condition persists, refer to Engine Diagnostic Manuals for trouble- shooting the ECM.
Check fuse F17 for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition and repair. Replace fuse.
At fuse F17 cavity A, measure voltage from circuit 13B to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 13B or 13A, then repair.
Is vehicle equipped with a manual transmission?
Disconnect clutch peddle conn. (386). Turn key on and at cavity C, measure voltage from circuit 97AU to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuits 97AU, 97P, or dash conn. (2), then repair.
Measure resistance of circuit 97L between conn. (386) cavity A, and relay (661) cavity 1/E.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 97L, then repair. Go to next step.
At (386), with clutch pedal released, measure switch resistance across term. B to C.
Clutch pdl. sw., term. B to C.
Replace clutch pedal switch and reconnect connector (386).
At (386) and with clutch pedal depressed, measure switch resistance across term. A to C.
Clutch pedal switch, term. A to C.
Clutch pedal sw. and cir. OK. Reconnect (386).
Replace clutch pedal switch and reconnect connector (386).
Disconnect neutral position switch conn. (438). Turn key on and measure voltage from circuit 97P to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 97P or dash conn. (2), then repair.
At switch (438) and with transmission in neutral, measure resistance across terminals.
At conn. (438), install jumper wire from cir. 97AU to ground. At crank relay (661) cav. 1, measure resistance of cir. 97L to ground.
Neutral position sw. and circuits OK. Reconnect (438).
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 97AU, 97L, or dash conn. (2) or jumper conn. (386), then repair. Reconnect (438).
Disconnect key switch conn. (24). At cavity E, measure voltage from circuit 15 to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 15, then repair.
Is vehicle equipped with key switch start?
Disconnect conn. (24A) from key switch. Install jumper from (24) cavity E to (24A) circuit 17. Does engine crank?
Replace key sw. Go to Step 29.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17, then repair.
Disconnect push button start switch conn. (135) or (521). Turn key on and measure voltage from circuit 17 to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17, then repair.
At (135) or (521), install jumper from circuit 17 to 17E. Does engine crank?
Replace push button. Go to next step.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17E or 17 (going to crank relay), then repair.
Cranking system circuitry checks good. If condition persists, refer to Engine Diagnostic Manuals to troubleshoot the ECM.
Remove conn. (417) from thermal switch and measure resistance across switch terminals (starter motor must not be hot).
With key in start position or push button depressed, at conn. (417) measure voltage to gnd. at circuit 17D.

Go to Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 for non-International engine
or to Engine Crank Inhibit system Circuit Testfor International engine.
With key in start position or push button depressed, at conn. (417) measure voltage between circuits 17D and 17-G.
Repair open in circuit 17-G or 11-G (17-G/11-GJ with International engine) to cranking motor ground stud.
